title-group.article-title: Ankle–Brachial Index as an Indicator of Arterial Stiffness in Patients Without Peripheral Artery Disease

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Medicine, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Simon W. Rabkin, Department of Medicine, Division of Cardiology, University of British Columbia, Level 9 2775 Laurel St, Vancouver, BC, Canada V5Z 1M9 Email: rabkin@interchange.ubc.ca

abstract.p: We tested the hypothesis that the Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) in patients without peripheral arterial disease ([PAD] ABI > 1.0) is an indicator of arterial stiffness. Fifty-five patients had measurement of carotid pulse wave contour, pulse wave velocity (PWV), and ABI. Vascular stiffness as assessed by augmentation index (AIx) showed a significant (P = .002) inverse correlation with ABI. Dichotomizing ABI into groups above and below the median showed that persons with a lower ABI, >1.0 to 1.5 (n = 27) had a significantly (P < .01) higher AIx than those with a higher ABI > 1.5 (n = 28). In contrast, vascular stiffness assessed by brachial-ankle or carotid femoral PWV did not correlate with ABI. In summary, ABI is an indicator of arterial stiffness assessed by AIx. Vascular changes detected by AIx are not the same as those detected by PWV. Assessment of ABI may have utility in cardiovascular risk assessment in patients without PAD.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Increased aortic stiffness is associated with increased risk of cardiovascular event even after considering standard risk factors.1-6 Arterial stiffness can be measured by pulse wave velocity (PWV)—the speed of travel of the pulse wave in the aorta or augmentation index (AIx)—the pressure increment from the shoulder of the systolic waveform. Each of these 2 indicators of arterial stiffness, PWV and AIx, predicts adverse cardiovascular events, although different studies describe different strength of the relationship.1–6 The measurement of arterial stiffness, however, can be time consuming. Another method of assessing the vasculature that is used for the evaluation of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is the ankle-brachial index (ABI), the ratio of the ankle systolic blood pressure (BP) to the brachial systolic BP. There is an inverse relationship between ABI and the presence of cardiovascular risk factors, clinical or subclinical cardiovascular disease, or the development of cardiovascular events.7,8 A systematic review of data comprising 44 590 participants from 6 different countries demonstrated consistently increased risk of cardiovascular disease with a low ABI (<0.9).9 Subsequent analysis of more studies focusing only on persons without prior history of coronary heart disease found that individuals with low ABI had an increase in total mortality and trend for increased cardiovascular mortality and the occurrence of major coronary events.10

Individuals with PAD have significantly increased aortic stiffness,11,12 although this has not been universally observed.13 The relationship of aortic stiffness to ABI in persons without PAD has not received much attention. The purpose of our study was to examine the hypothesis that ABI within the “normal” range is an indicator of vascular stiffness. We further sought to compare the 2 different indicators of arterial stiffness AIx and PWV with respect to their relationship to ABI.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Patients from a cardiology clinic at a University teaching hospital, who did not have PAD, and who did not have valvular heart disease that would alter carotid pulse contour, were examined. The ABI, PWV, and AIx were measured using an Omron Colin VP1000/2000 (Illinois). The ABI was measured using an automated oscillatory method, with the participants rested in the supine position. The BP was measured with cuffs applied to both arms (for determination of brachial BP) and to both ankles (for determination of ankle BP). The ABI was calculated as the ratio of ankle-to-brachial systolic BP. Measurements from the left- and right-hand sides of each patient were averaged to 1 value for each individual. Patients were included in the study as long as they did not have known PAD on history (intermittent claudication) or on clinical examination (reduced pedal pulses) and all persons had to have an ABI of >1.0

The right carotid pulse wave and femoral artery contours were recorded simultaneously by placement of a transducer over these arteries. An electrocardiogram was recorded from electrodes placed on both wrists. Using the carotid pressure waveform, the AIx was calculated as the difference between the second and the first systolic shoulder and expressed as a percentage of the carotid pulse contour. The PWV was the distance in meters (based on patient’s height) from the carotid to the femoral artery or brachial artery to ankle (baPWV) divided by transit time.
Data are reported as the mean ± standard deviation. Hypothesis testing used either linear correlation analysis or student t test. The null hypothesis was rejected at P < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The mean age was 62.7 years (range 38-82 years) and 68.5% were men (Table 1). Body mass index was 27 kg/m2. A minority, one third of the group (32.7%), were on vasoactive drugs, with 11 on single-drug therapy (4 calcium channel blockers [CCBs]; 4 angiotensin receptor blockers [ARBs] or angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors [ACEi]; 2 diuretics and 1 β-blocker); and 7 on combination therapy (2 each on CCB plus ARB/ACEi, CCB plus β-blocker, 2 diuretic plus ARBs/ACEi, and 1 diuretic plus ARBs/ACEi). The mean ABI was 1.16. There was a highly significant (P < .005) correlation between ABI and AIx (Figure 1). Dichotomizing ABI into groups above and below the median showed that persons with a lower ABI, >1.0 to 1.5 (n = 27), had a significantly higher AIx than those with a higher ABI, > 1.5 (n = 28).

sec.p: There was no significant correlation between ABI or AIx and either age or BP while PWV correlated with BP (Table 2). The ABI did not correlate with heart rate but both AIx and PWV correlated with heart rate. Augmentation index correlated significantly with the body mass index (r = −.30, P < .05), but there was no correlation between ABI or PWV and body mass index.

sec.p: There was no significant relationship between ABI and PWV in the segments from baPWV or carotid to femoral artery (cfPWV; Figure 2). Consistent with this finding, there was no significant correlation between AIx and baPWV (r = .155; P = .26) or cfPWV (r = .024, P = .8). Another way of evaluating the transmission of BP to the legs is by assessing the absolute difference between the systolic BP in the brachial artery and ankle. Blood pressure in the ankle is usually greater than that at the brachial artery so that the difference is a negative value. There was a significant correlation between brachial-ankle pressure gradient and AIx (Figure 3). There was no correlation between pulse pressure and ABI, Alx, or baPWV.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The major finding of this study is that ABI, in the range that is not considered diagnositic for PAD, was associated with one marker of arterial stiffness. The ABI was inversely related to AIx. The AIx has traditionally been considered an indication of the extent of wave reflection and increased wave reflection has been interpreted as an indicator of increased arterial stiffness.14 Recent studies have focused on the capacitive or reservoir function of the aorta and large elastic arteries and contend that while the onset of pressure augmentation is determined by the arrival of the backward-traveling (reflected) wave, the degree of AIx is principally determined by the arterial reservoir function.15 Increased AIx is directly attributed to a reduction in the reservoir function—compliance properties of the aorta and other elastic arteries.15 Another possible explanation for this association is the development of arterial calcification which increases arterial stiffness16 and can involve abnormalities of calcium/phosphate as well as neurohormonal factors operative in hypertension.16,17 Regardless of the underlying physiologic explanation for the magnitude of AIx—wave reflection or aortic capacitance—increased AIx is an indicator of increased arterial stiffness. Thus, the inverse association between ABI and AIx suggests that ABI is an indicator of arterial stiffness. The mechanism responsible for the correlation of ABI with AIx cannot be explained by an indirect correlation of either ABI or AI with age, BP, or pulse pressure because there was no significant correlation between ABI or AIx and each of these factors in this study population. These and other correlations must be viewed within the caveat of the smaller sample size in this study. The absence of a correlation with pulse pressure underscores the reason why pulse pressure cannot simply be used to replace the measurement of ABI. While we use the terms arterial stiffness, aortic stiffness, and vascular stiffness, it is important to remember that these terms may encompass abnormalities in separate measures of arterial compliance, distensibility, pressure augmentation, or wave reflection in different segments of the vasculature. While AIx and PWV correlated with heart rate, there was no correlation between ABI and heart rate, excluding the possibility that the association of ABI with AIx was operative through heart rate. While there was a correlation of AI with body mass index, there was no correlation between ABI and body mass index. Thus, it is unlikely that the relationship of ABI and AIx was operative through BMI.

We found no relationship between ABI and PWV measured as baPWV or cfPWV. The cfPWV is a good predictor of development of clinical cardiovascular events1; baPWV is a good method to measure vascular stiffness and indicator of generalized cardiovascular disease.18–20 Although both baPWV and cfPWV provides qualitatively similar information about arterial stiffness21 and exhibit similar extent of associations with cardiovascular disease risk factors and clinical events,22 cfPWV is more widely accepted in Europe and North America,1 while baPWV is widely used in Japan and other east Asian countries.21,22 We evaluated using both baPWV and cfPWV and neither showed a relationship to ABI.

While both AIx and PWV measure arterial stiffness, our data support the concept that AI and PWV measure different components of arterial stiffness because there was a clear difference in the higher and significant correlation between ABI and AIx and the absence of a similar correlation between ABI and PWV. The differences between assessment of aortic stiffness by AIx and PWV have been outlined in reviews.23,24 The relationship between AIx and PWV is purported better as the aorta becomes stiffer.25 Which of the structural and cellular elements of the vessel wall, such as calcification, scaffolding proteins, and extracellular matrix,26 correlate best with AIx or PWV requires further study, but it is noteworthy that aortic calcification assessed by CT scan correlated with PWV and not AI in healthy individuals.16 Our data are different from those of Tarumi et al who found a positive association between mean ankle BP and AIx.27 However, they primarily studied27 an Asian population with a younger age (47 years) with a slight excess of women to men and excluded participants with an ABI >1.3. Our finding of a significant negative correlation between ABI and AI is consistent with the community study in Rochester, Minnesota, which was different from our study in that they did not exclude persons with PAD and indeed had 12% of participants with ABI <1.0.28 High ABI has been associated with an increased mortality, suggesting a U-shaped association between ABI as a noninvasive measure of PAD and an indicator of mortality risk.29

Several limitations of this study should be kept in mind. The study population came from an outpatient clinic population and the findings may not be representative of the normal population. The sample size is relatively small but meaningful correlations are still possible with this patient population. Second, patients were excluded from the study based on clinical evidence of PAD and low ABI (<1.0). There were no angiograms performed to identify persons with subclinical PAD. Such studies, however, could not be justified. Third, ABI was measured by an automated oscillatory method rather than continuous wave Doppler ultrasound. However, the oscillatory method has been shown to be an accurate and efficient method to measure ABI.30 Fourth, although some vasoactive/antihypertensive drugs can alter arterial stiffness, a minority—one third of the group—were on vasoactive drugs with the kind of drug being equally distributed among the different antihypertensive drug classes. Fifth, although some would argue that measurement of ABI is not likely to be clinically used in asymptomatic patients for the purpose of detecting subclinical presence of elevated arterial stiffness, it is equally reasonable to believe that a method to assess the vasculature such as ABI is simpler to perform than measurements of arterial stiffness in asymptomatic patients. Sixth, we did not standardize AIx or PWV for heart rate. The reason is that the measurement of PWV and AIx were done simultaneous so that the heart rate was the same in each individual at the time of measurement of PWV and AIx.

In summary, in persons without PAD, the measurement of ABI is a useful indicator of aortic stiffness measured by AIx. Vascular stiffening is produced by complex interactions between stable and dynamic changes involving structural and cellular elements of the vessel wall, such as calcification, scaffolding proteins, extracellular matrix, inflammatory molecules, endothelial cell function, and reactive oxidant species that are in turn influenced by hemodynamic forces and extrinsic factors such as hormones, salt, and glucose regulation.26 The unique relationship between ABI and AIx rather than PWV suggests that lower ABI is associated with a change in aortic compliance or wave reflectance that is more readily detectable by changes in AIx than PWV. Considering that AIx is an indicator of the development of cardiovascular events,3,5 assessment of ABI or the absolute the difference in systolic pressure at the ankle compared with the brachial artery may have utility in cardiovascular risk assessment in patients without PAD.
